text: I wanted to share this new Kepler solver <https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15829> but I see <@U8442MDS6> is already on it :smile: i feel like a Julia implementation would be pretty fast (especially using `sincos`), but I believe this method is also way more expensive than <https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00691917> (and the fact that they don't mention Markley's solver makes me think they don't know it)

attachments.title: Kepler Equation solver
attachments.text: Kepler's Equation is solved over the entire range of elliptic motion by a fifth-order refinement of the solution of a cubic equation. This method is not iterative, and requires only four transcendental function evaluations: a square root, a cube root, and two trigonometric functions. The maximum relative error of the algorithm is less than one part in 1018, exceeding the capability of double-precision computer arithmetic. Roundoff errors in double-precision implementation of the algorithm are addressed, and procedures to avoid them are developed.
attachments.fallback: Celestial Mechanics and Dynamical Astronomy: Kepler Equation solver

text:
```julia> using AstroLib, DirectOrbits, BenchmarkTools

julia> @btime kepler_solver(0.5, 0.5)
  100.795 ns (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
0.8878622115708661

julia> @btime DirectOrbits.eccentric_anomaly(0.5, 0.5)
  1.664 μs (22 allocations: 2.17 KiB)
0.8878622115708661```

text:
```julia> using AstroLib, DirectOrbits

julia> M = collect(range(-pi, pi; length=1_000_000));

julia> ecc = 0.5
0.5

julia> E_goat = DirectOrbits.eccentric_anomaly_goat.(M, ecc);

julia> E_markley = kepler_solver.(M, ecc);

julia> extrema(abs.(M .- rem2pi.(E_markley .- 0.5 .* sin.(E_markley), RoundNearest)))
(0.0, 4.440892098500626e-16)

julia> extrema(abs.(M .- rem2pi.(E_goat .- 0.5 .* sin.(E_goat), RoundNearest)))
(1.453948073049105e-12, 3.137922125546848)```
the error looks pretty bad :confused:
